results.title: The Joy of effort (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Roman Bittman and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
The scientific study of human movement in various sports to discover principles which can be applied by sports coaches. Shows testing and measuring different areas of fitness, for example a runner, skater, and a gymnast.

results.title: And God created great whales
results.creator_credit: Roman Bittman and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Observations of the killer whale in captivity and in the sea indicate that it is both gregarious and intelligent. Its survival is now threatened

results.title: The Last of life
results.creator_credit: Diederik d'Ailly and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
About research into the processes of human ageing. Examines the needs of old people and emphasises that it is essential that old people retain a sense of self respect. Narrated by Valerie Elia.

Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.

results.title: Out of the mouths of babes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Focuses on Peter and Jill de Villiers, two Harvard researchers, and their contention that knowledge of a language is innate in humans and develops as the child matures biologically. Includes interviews with both scientists and highlights their work. Suitable for tertiary/teacher level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.

results.title: Garbage ouroboros
results.creator_credit: Milan Chuostek and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Municipal garbage is Public Enemy No. 1. While nature always recycles, man is the first animal who has broken the cycle. We must design for re-use, for to eliminate waste is to eliminate pollution. This program shows what amateurs and professionals are doing in Canada and the United States and makes suggestions for further strategies.
results.description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.

This program shows what amateurs and professionals are doing in Canada and the United States and makes suggestions for further strategies.

results.title: The Elephant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Jiminy Cricket tells the history of the evolution of the elephant, from prehistoric mastodons and mammoths; describes the elephant of today and how it uses its trunk; and shows how the Indian mahout trains his elephant to work.

results.title: The Differences are inherited
results.creator_credit: Diederik d'Ailly and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
A highly visual exposition of heredity. Features an outstanding production combination in which the already rapid growth cycle of the fruit fly is speeded up through time lapse photography to show the actual development of living beings, both normal and abnormal.

group_works.title: Testing hypotheses
group_works.creator_credit: Dick Larson and Coronet Instructional Media

results.title: Testing hypotheses
results.creator_credit: Dick Larson and Coronet Instructional Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of Science”
Scientific hypotheses don’t gain much respect until they have been tested. Some can be tested experimentally, others only through the weight of evidence. Pasteur’s classic experiments relating to spontaneous generation illustrate the former and the mass of evidence supporting theories of evolution illustrate the latter. For primary grades.
